title: The Concept of Limits
text:
The concept of a limit was first introduced in the 1600's by Sir Isaac Newton. Mathematicians practicing Calculus needed a way to determine the rate of change (\(\Delta\)) between two points on a curve that were infinitesimally apart so that they could find the Instantaneous Rate of Change.
Definition
Instantaneous Rate of Change: the rate of change \((\Delta)\) between two points on a curve that are infinitesimally apart.
Thus, came the introduction of Limits that helped determine that the instantaneous rate of change could be determined as long as the points were on the same curve or were at least on an adjacent curve. This introduces another concept known as Continuity which will be briefly discussed in a later section. Limits can help us answer the following questions:
  • How fast was a car accelerating at a single moment in time?
  • What is the velocity required to escape earth's gravitational force, also known as escape velocity ? Answer: \(11\text{km/s}\)
The next section will go over the definition of a limit which, without doubt is the hardest section in this tutorial. That being said, if you find yourself understanding it, then the subsequent sections will be cake.

title: The Formal Definition of a Limit
text: $$\text{Given a function $f(x)$ that is defined on an open interval $(a, b)$}$$ $$\text{We can find the $\bold{limit}$ of $n$ where $n \in (a,b)$}$$ $$\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~n} f(x) = L$$ $$ \text{If for every $\epsilon \gt 0$, there exists a $\delta \gt 0$ such that} $$ $$ \text{if $0 \lt \lvert~ x ~-~n ~\rvert \lt \delta$ $\quad$ then $\quad$ $\lvert ~ f(x) ~ - ~ L ~ \rvert \lt \epsilon$ } $$ $$ \text{When we find the limit $L$, we say the limit of $f(x)$ as $x$ approaches $n$ is $L$} $$ If we try and break this definition down into parts, it might be a little easier to digest. To start, we are going to assume that there exists a limit for \(f(x)\) as \(x\) approaches \(n\), and we will call it \(L\). In other words, assume \(L\) is the limit for \(f(x)\) as \(x\) approaches \(n\), where \(n \in (a,b)\). In order to prove this assumption, there needs to exist a \(\delta \gt 0\) for every \(\epsilon \gt 0\) where the distance between \(f(x)\) and \(L\) is less than \(\epsilon\) and the distance between \(x\) and \(n\) is less than \(\delta\) as \(x\) approaches \(n\). So, the question then becomes, how can we always guarantee that for every \(\epsilon \gt 0\), there also exists a \(\delta \gt 0\) that satisfies the requirement above ? The answer is quite simple; Represent \(\textbf{$\delta$}\) as a function of \(\textbf{$\epsilon$}\). Representing \(\delta\) as a function of \(\epsilon\) works because we are trying to determine if we can find a \(\delta\) for every \(\epsilon \gt 0\), and if we can determine a value for \(\delta\) that is computed using \(\epsilon\), then that means for every \(\epsilon \gt 0\) there will always be a value for \(\delta\) that satisfies the case. Let's do an example. $$\text{Given $f(x) = 5x$ ~~ prove that $\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~2} f(x) = 10 $ using $\epsilon$ - $\delta$.}$$ In order to prove this claim, we will need to represent delta \((\delta)\) as a function of epsilon \((\epsilon\)). So, in order for us to do that, we will need to work backwards, meaning that we will need to start with the \(\epsilon\) part of the definition, specifically \( \lvert f(x) - 10 \rvert \) and try and reduce/factor it so that it equates to the \(\delta\) part, \( \lvert x - 2 \rvert \). $$ \begin{aligned} \lvert f(x) - 10 \rvert \lt \epsilon \\ \lvert 5x - 10 \rvert \lt \epsilon \\ 5\lvert x - 2 \rvert \lt \epsilon \\ \lvert x - 2 \rvert \lt \frac{\epsilon}{5} \end{aligned} $$ As you can see, we managed to go from \(\lvert f(x) - 10 \rvert\) to \(\lvert x - 2 \rvert \) which means that we can now claim that setting \(\delta = \frac{\epsilon}{5}\) will satisfy the limit. To verify, $$ \begin{aligned} \lvert x - 2 \rvert &\lt \delta && \text{substitute $\frac{\epsilon}{5}$ for $\delta$} \\ \lvert x - 2 \rvert &\lt \frac{\epsilon}{5} \\ 5\lvert x - 2 \rvert &\lt \epsilon \\ \lvert 5x - 10 \rvert &\lt \epsilon \\ \lvert f(x) - 10 \rvert &\lt \epsilon && \text{$\square$} \end{aligned} $$ Now that we have the definition of a limit covered, the next section will cover Continuity which is an important topic closely related to Limits.

title: Continuity & Limits
text:
Continuity is a concept that deserves a tutorial all on its own, but for the purposes of this tutorial, a brief overview should be enough.

$$\text{Suppose we are given a function $f(x)$ and an interval $(a, b)$. If $f(x)$ is defined for every $k \in (a, b)$, then $f(x)$ is $\textbf{continuous}$ along the interval $(a, b)$.}$$

To put it informally,

$$\text{If you can draw the graph of $f(x)$ along the interval $(a, b)$ without taking your pencil off the paper, then $f(x)$ is continuous along $(a, b)$.}$$

Now, suppose we are given a function \(g(x)\) that is continuous along the real line \((\textbf{R})\). Since its continuous, it has certain properties that we can use to help us find limits. This first being that for any number \(k \in \textbf{R}\), we can guarantee that the limit will be defined as \(x \rightarrow k\) simply because \(g(x)\) is defined near \(k\) as well as at \(k\).

Moreover, knowing that \(g(x)\) is continuous, means that we can also guarantee that as \(x \rightarrow k\), \(g(x)\) will be converging towards \(g(k)\). This is powerful because we can then claim that the \( \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~k} g(x) = g(k) \). 

Formally put,

$$\text{if $g(x)$ is a \textbf{continuous function} along the real line, then for any $k \in \textbf{R}$ $\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~k} g(x) = g(k)$ }$$
We can then also claim that,
$$\text{if $\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~k} g(x) = g(k)$, then $\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~k^-} g(x) = \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~k^+} g(x) = g(k)$}$$

title: Understanding Limits by Example
text:
Consider the following, $$\text{Given $f(x) = x$, find} \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~2} f(x) $$ If we think about the domain of \( f(x) \), \(\text{D} =\{ x \in \mathbb{R} \} \), meaning that \( f(x) \) is defined along the real line. Because the domain covers the entire real line, we can say that \( f(x) \) is a continuous function. Now, since \( f(x) \) is continuous, we can do some calculations near \( x = 2 \) to determine what the limit is as \(x\) approaches \(2\).
\(f(x) ~~ \text{where} ~~ x \gt 2 ~ \text{(approaching 2 from the right)}\)\( f(x) ~~ \text{where} ~~ x \lt 2 ~ \text{(approaching 2 from the left)} \)
\(3\)\(1\)
\(2.5\)\(1.5\)
\(2.1\)\(1.9\)
\(2.01\)\(1.99\)
\(2.001\)\(1.999\)
\(2.0001\)\(1.9999\)
As you can see, as \( x \) approaches \( 2 \) from the left and right (think of a number line), \( f(x) \) is converging towards \( 2\). $$\text{Given $f(x) = x$, the limit of $f(x)$ as $x$ approaches $2$ is $2$}$$ $$\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~2} f(x) = 2 \quad \text{$\square$} $$ To further elaborate on the answer, take a look at the graph of \(f(x) = x \). You can see by inspection that as \(x\) gets closer to \(2\), \(f(x)\) also gets closer and closer to \(f(2) = 2\).

title: Understanding when limits are undefined
text:
There exists functions who are discontinuous and fail to have a limit at every point on it's curve. This occurs when the limit at some point \(a\) from the left does not equal the limit from the right. Formally put, $$\text{if} ~ \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~a^-} f(x) \not= \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~a^+} f(x), ~ \text{ then} \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~a} f(x) = \text{undefined}$$ Let's take a take a look at the following example, $$\text{Consider} ~ g(x) = \frac{1}{x}; \quad \text{Find}\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~0} g(x)$$
Looking at the graph, we can see that there exists an asymptote at \( x = 0 \). Our strategy of finding the limit as \(x\) approaches \(0\) will be to find the limit from the left and right of \(0\). To start, let's find the \( \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~0^-} g(x)\) (the limit as \(x\) approaches \(0\) from the right). By inspection, we can see that as we approach \(0\) from the right, \(g(x)\) is getting more and more negative. In fact, since there is an asymptote at \(x = 0\), we say that \(g(x)\) is getting infinitely negative as \(x\) approaches \(0\) from the right. $$\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~0^-} g(x) = -\infty$$ Now that we figured out what the limit is from the right of \(0\), let's find the limit from the left of \(0\). Once more, we can apply the same thinking from finding the limit from the right of \(0\). Simply put, \(g(x)\) is getting infinitely positive as \(x\) approaches \(0\) from the left. $$\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~0^-} g(x) = +\infty$$ Now that we have found the limit of \(0\) from the left and right of \(0\) let's compare them and see if they match. $$\begin{aligned} \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~0^-} g(x) &= \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~0^+} g(x)\\ -\infty &\not= +\infty \\ \end{aligned}$$ Seeing that the limits from the left and right of \(0\) are not equal, we can conclude that $$\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~0} g(x) = \text{undefined} \quad \text{$\square$}$$

title: Defined limits for discontinous functions
text:
Consider, $$f(x) = \begin{cases} x &\text{if } x \not= 2 \\ 1 &\text{if } x = 2 \end{cases}$$ If we were to plot this piecewise function, we would get the following
This piecewise function is considered as a discontinuous function. If you look at the point \( (2,2) \) you'll notice an empty point. You'll also notice that below it is the actual point \( (2,1) \), and this is what is called a \(~\textbf{jump}~\) in the graph. So, if we were asked to find the limit of \( f(x) \) as \( x \) approaches \(2\), what do you think the result would be ? undefined ? maybe. Let's find out. $$\text{Find the} \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~2} f(x)$$ The way to approach this problem is to take a look at what happens on the graph of \( f(x) \) as \(x\) approaches \(2\) from the left and right. From the left, we can see that \( f(x) \) approaches \(2\) but never actually get there. That's ok though, because when we talk about limits, we never consider the actual point \( (2, f(2)) \) to be the limit as \(x\) approaches 2 simply because \( f(x) \) is not a continuous function. We can then say that, $$\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~2^-} f(x) = 2$$ From the right, we can see the same thing happening. As \( x \) approaches \(2\) from the right, \( f(x) \) gets closer and closer to \(2\) but never actually gets there. Just like the limit from the left side, we can say that, $$\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~2^+} f(x) = 2$$ Now, if you haven't noticed, the limit from the left and the limit from the right side of \( 2 \) are equal. Knowing this, we can claim that, $$\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~2} f(x) = 2 \quad \text{$\square$}$$ So, what we just learned is that, even though the function is discontinuous at a point, does not necessarily mean that the limit at the point is undefined. It is possible for a limit to exist even though there is a jump at the respected point.
